ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Diagram execution begins with the Start block. There can be only one such block in the diagram.

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Caption: WriteToLog
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Numeric, text constant (in quotation marks), variable name (beginning with $) or any expression whose value will be logged during robot script execution. The value can also be of a complex data type, such as a List, Table, or Hashtable.

Properties.Name: Variable1
Properties.Caption: Variable1
Properties.Tooltip: [Variable] Name of the first variable to assign a new value to. You can select a variable from the drop-down list that was previously declared in the Variables panel, and enter the name of a new or previously used variable in another block, even if it was not declared in the Variables panel.

Properties.Name: Expression1
Properties.Caption: Value1
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] New value of the first variable. The property is ignored if the name of the first variable is not assigned. The new value of a variable can be either a constant (a number, a literal string), or an expression using other variables and/or functions. In the new variable value, using an expression involving the same variable is allowed. Remember that here and in other blocks, variable names used in expressions should begin with the $ symbol, and string constants should be enclosed within quotation marks.

Properties.Name: SendOrkest
Properties.Caption: LogToOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the text will also be logged to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: IsScreenshot
Properties.Caption: ScreenshotInOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, a screenshot will be taken and sent to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorDirection
Properties.Caption: OutputDirection
Properties.Tooltip: Select a block output direction in case of a failure. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Right" - to the right; "Bottom" - to the bottom. With this option, it is possible to determine output direction for blocks with no "If Error" connector (for example, "Condition" block) in case of an error. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block denotes the script completion or the return from the subprocess diagram to the main process. In a diagram, more than one End block can be used. There should be at least one such block in the subprocess diagram, otherwise after the subprocess completion, there will be no return to the main process.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows to create scripts consisting of several diagrams. The script execution will continue from the Start block of the specified project diagram. The script execution will return to the current block and continue in the current diagram as soon as the End block in the external diagram is reached.

Properties.Name: DiagramName
Properties.Caption: DiagramName
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] The file name of the diagram, in which the script execution will continue. To create a new subprocess, set the name of the new diagram in this property, and then press the "Open" button in the block itself.

Properties.Name: ProcessArguments
Properties.Caption: Arguments
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Arguments for calling the diagram. To edit the value, you must use the button on the block with the hint "Arguments"

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorDirection
Properties.Caption: OutputDirection

With this option, it is possible to determine output direction for blocks with no "If Error" connector (for example, "Condition" block) in case of an error. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows for entering any text comment in the diagram. The block is not part of the script
The block can be used as a stub or a reminder for the functions planned for implementation. Unlike the Comment block, this block is an element of the script, but does not perform any actions.

Allows for outputting random messages and/or variable values to the log during the robot script run. The messages will be available for viewing in the Log panel of the designer program, as well as in the text files of the robot program logs.

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Caption: WriteToLog
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Numeric, text constant (in quotation marks), variable name (beginning with $) or any expression whose value will be logged during robot script execution. The value can also be of a complex data type, such as a List, Table, or Hashtable.

Properties.Name: MakeScreenshot
Properties.Caption: MakeScreenshot
Properties.Tooltip: Makes a screenshot and saves it in the log folder

Properties.Name: SendOrkest
Properties.Caption: LogToOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the text will also be logged to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: IsScreenshot
Properties.Caption: ScreenshotInOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, a screenshot will be taken and sent to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: Level
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Message level when sending log to orchestrator

Properties.Name: ShowStatus
Properties.Caption: DisplayInStatus
Properties.Tooltip: If enabled, the text will also be displayed in the status, at the top of the screen

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block checks the specified condition for truth and, depending on the result, the execution of the script continues in the direction of the "Yes" (condition satisfied) or "No" (condition not satisfied) output. For example, condition $a == "Hello" checks whether the value of variable $a is equal to value "Hello", and condition $Result > 5 checks whether the value of variable $Result exceeds value 5. A condition can contain mathematical and logical operations, constants, functions, other variables, etc. Examples of expressions that can be used in conditions are available by pressing the ... button next to the Condition property.

Properties.Name: Condition
Properties.Caption: Condition
Properties.Tooltip: [Any Expression] Depending on the value of this expression, the script execution will continue with the "Yes" or "No" output. The value of an expression equivalent to 0 (zero) or $False is equated to "No"; all other values are equated to "Yes". For example, if value 5 was previously assigned to variable $a, then condition $a>2 is true, and condition $a == 6 is false.

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorDirection
Properties.Caption: OutputDirection
Properties.Tooltip: Select a block output direction in case of a failure. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Right" - to the right; "Bottom" - to the bottom. With this option, it is possible to determine output direction for blocks with no "If Error" connector (for example, "Condition" block) in case of an error. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The switch statement compares the expression result with the specified values ​​and exits using the specified connector. If no matches are found, exits via the "Default" connector

Properties.Name: Statement
Properties.Caption: ExpressionToEvaluate
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Comparable expression

Properties.Name: Condition1
Properties.Caption: Condition1
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Condition 1. If matched, connector 1 will be exited and expression 1 will be executed if specified. If the connector is not specified, then exit will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Expression1
Properties.Caption: Expression1
Properties.Tooltip: [Expression] If condition 1 is met, this expression will be executed and an exit will be made through the corresponding connector. If the connector is not connected, then the output will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Condition2
Properties.Caption: Condition2
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Condition 2. If matched, connector 1 will be exited and expression 1 will be executed if specified. If the connector is not specified, then exit will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Expression2
Properties.Caption: Expression2
Properties.Tooltip: [Expression] If condition 2 is met, this expression will be executed and an exit will be made through the corresponding connector. If the connector is not connected, then the output will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Condition3
Properties.Caption: Condition3
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Condition 3. If matched, connector 1 will be exited and expression 1 will be executed if specified. If the connector is not specified, then exit will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Expression3
Properties.Caption: Expression3
Properties.Tooltip: [Expression] If condition 3 is met, this expression will be executed and an exit will be made through the corresponding connector. If the connector is not connected, then the output will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Condition4
Properties.Caption: Condition4
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Condition 4. If matched, connector 1 will be exited and expression 1 will be executed if specified. If the connector is not specified, then exit will be performed by default

Properties.Name: Expression4
Properties.Caption: Expression4

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block sets new values for one or more variables. The new value of a variable can be either a constant (a number, a literal string), or an expression using other variables and/or functions. In the new variable value, using an expression involving the same variable is allowed. Remember that here and in other blocks, variable names used in expressions should begin with the $ symbol, and string constants should be enclosed within quotation marks. A variable can be selected from among those declared in the Variables panel, and the name of a new variable or a variable previously used in other blocks can also be manually entered, even if this variable was not declared in the Variables panel. Examples of expressions that can be used in the Value properties are available by pressing the ... buttons next to the relevant properties.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Iterates through all the elements in the preset List; in each iteration of the loop, it assigns the current element to the variable that is specified in the Item property, and then the script execution continues towards the Item output of this block (in the so-called "loop body"). After iterating all the elements of the list, the script execution continues towards the lower output of the block. Be sure to connect the output of the last block in the loop body with the input of this block or any of the preceding blocks.

Properties.Name: Item

Properties.Name: ItemIndex
Properties.Caption: ItemIndex
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Ordinal number of the element. Numbering starts from zero

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Iterates through all the elements (of the Key-Value couple) in the preset Hashtable; in each iteration of the loop, it assigns the current Hashtable element to the variables that are specified in the Key and Value properties, and then the script execution continues towards the Item output of this block (in the so-called "loop body"). After iterating all the elements of the Hashtable, the script execution continues towards the lower output of the block. Be sure to connect the output of the last block in the loop body with the input of this block or any of the preceding blocks.

Properties.Name: Items

Properties.Name: Value

Properties.Name: ItemIndex

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The loop allows for repeating a chain of actions (blocks) several times and at the same time counting the number of the loop iterations, writing the current number to a special variable (specified in the Index property), which can then be used in other blocks. With the first entry into the block, the value of the variable from the Index property is equated to the Initial Value, and then the script execution continues towards the Loop output of this block (into the so-called "loop body"). As soon as the execution of the script reaches this block again, the value of the Index variable will increase by the Increment value, and the jump towards the Loop output will occur again. As soon as the value of the Index variable becomes greater than or equal to the Final Value, the script execution will continue towards the lower output of the block. Be sure to connect the output of the last block in the loop body with the input of this block or any of the preceding blocks.

Properties.Name: StartIndex
Properties.Caption: InitialValue
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Initial value of the variable from the Loop property will be assigned to this variable at the beginning of the loop

Properties.Name: EndIndex
Properties.Caption: FinalValue
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Final value of the variable from the Loop property. Loop iterations will be run as long as the value of the Loop variable is less than the value preset in this property

Properties.Name: Step
Properties.Caption: Increment
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Variable value increment from the Loop property in each loop iteration. The increment can have a negative value; this is useful when the Initial Value is greater than the Final Value, and you need to count down.

Properties.Name: Index
Properties.Caption: Index
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Variable, to which the current value of the loop will be written. For example: if the Initial Value = 0, the Final Value = 7, and the Increment = 2, then the values of the loop will be numbers 0,2,4,6 sequentially.

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The loop allows for repeating a chain of actions (blocks) several times while the condition preset in the form of an expression is satisfied. With each entry into the block, the expression specified in the Condition property is checked, and if it is true, the script execution will continue towards the Loop output of this block (into the so-called "loop body"). As soon as the Condition ceases to be fulfilled during the next pass through this block, the script will continue towards the lower output of the block. Be sure to connect the output of the last block in the loop body with the input of this block or any of the preceding blocks.

Properties.Name: Condition
Properties.Caption: Condition
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] As long as the specified expression has a true value, the loop will continue to run. An expression value equivalent to 0 (zero) or $False is considered false, and any other values are considered true. For example, if value 5 was previously assigned to variable $a, then condition $a>2 is true, and condition $a == 6 is false. A condition can contain mathematical and logical operations, constants, functions, other variables, etc. Examples of expressions that can be used in conditions are available by pressing the ... button next to the Condition property.

Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block implements the Try/Catch construct. To work correctly, the blocks of this container must end with an "End" block. If an error occurs in the blocks, an output will be performed via the "If error" connector. Otherwise, on the "Exit" connector. To mimic the Finally construct, manual connection of the blocks after handling the error to the Exit connector blocks is required. If no block is connected to the "If Error" connector, then the error will be ignored and the exit will be made via the "Exit" connector. If the "Output" connector is not connected, then in the absence of an error, a return from the current diagram will be made

Properties.Name: NumberAttempts
Properties.Caption: NumberOfAttempts
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] The block will not be released by the "If error" connector until the specified number of attempts is completed

Properties.Name: Variable1
Properties.Caption: Variable1
Properties.Tooltip: [Variable] Name of the first variable to assign a new value to. You can select a variable from the drop-down list that was previously declared in the Variables panel, and enter the name of a new or previously used variable in another block, even if it was not declared in the Variables panel.

Properties.Name: Expression1
Properties.Caption: Value1
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] New value of the first variable. The property is ignored if the name of the first variable is not assigned. The new value of a variable can be either a constant (a number, a literal string), or an expression using other variables and/or functions. In the new variable value, using an expression involving the same variable is allowed. Remember that here and in other blocks, variable names used in expressions should begin with the $ symbol, and string constants should be enclosed within quotation marks.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Allows to visually collapse a sequence of blocks to make more space in the diagram. The sequence of blocks connected to this block should be terminated with "End" block. After "End" block is met, the flow of diagram continues via Exit output of this block. You can also use Abort Container block inside the sequence to continue flow of diagram without returning to the Exit output of Collapse block.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Raises exception (error) which can be either handled by the script or will cause script termination. Allows to distinguish between System and Business errors which can be used in a robot framework architecture.

Properties.Name: ThrowException
Properties.Caption: GenerateError
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] The given value will be generated as an error. If the value is not set, then the script will be terminated.

Properties.Name: TypeException
Properties.Caption: ErrorType
Properties.Tooltip: Select the error type to generate. Possible values: Default - normal exception; System - system exception (the value of the $SystemException variable is set); Business - business exception (the value of the $BusinessException variable is set)

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Caption: WriteToLog
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Numeric, text constant (in quotation marks), variable name (beginning with $) or any expression whose value will be logged during robot script execution. The value can also be of a complex data type, such as a List, Table, or Hashtable.

Properties.Name: SendOrkest
Properties.Caption: LogToOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the text will also be logged to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: IsScreenshot
Properties.Caption: ScreenshotInOrchestrator
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, a screenshot will be taken and sent to the orchestrator if the connection to it is active

Properties.Name: SetJobFailed
Properties.Caption: SetFailedStatus
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the work status will be forcibly set as Failed. The property works only if the value of the "Generate error" property is not set

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows you to exit anywhere from the container (Try/Catch, Container). By default, to exit the container, you must set the "End" block. After that, the container will be exited via the "Exit" connector. If there is a need to exit the container anywhere, then you need to install this block and continue the script after it. If further in the script there is an "End" block, then it will end either the previous container or the entire diagram. If the "Abort Container" block is outside the container's work, then it will not return from the diagram

Properties.Name: Value
Properties.Caption: WriteToLog
Properties.Tooltip: [Any data type] Numeric, text constant (in quotation marks), variable name (beginning with $) or any expression whose value will be logged during robot script execution. The value can also be of a complex data type, such as a List, Table, or Hashtable.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows pseudo-parallel execution of one of the blocks directly connected to its outputs, selecting the block in which an error does not occur, and after the successful execution of such a block, continue the script. A connected block is considered successful if it did not throw an error (exception). The "If Error" connector of all directly connected units must remain empty. If none of the blocks directly connected to the outputs succeeded (all blocks threw an exception), attempts to execute these blocks are repeated until one of the blocks succeeds, or until a timeout occurs. Popular usage scenarios: waiting for one of several selectors to appear on the screen (you need to connect Wait for element blocks to outputs), wait for files in folders, etc. If the plug-in has its own configurable timeout, it is recommended to set it to the minimum possible value

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Block execution timeout limit in seconds

Properties.Name: OutStatus
Properties.Caption: OutStatus
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Returns the number of the executed block. The number starts at 1 and corresponds to the connector number. If the status is zero, then the block timeout has expired and none of the connected blocks have been successfully executed

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Start Background Robot

Properties.Name: NameFileRobot
Properties.Caption: FileRobot
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Robot file with .robot extension. Either the relative path or the full path to the file is specified.

Properties.Name: LaunchMode
Properties.Caption: RunMode
Properties.Tooltip: Robot start mode. Possible options: Background - the robot runs in the background, Foreground (PiP) - the robot will run in PiP (Picture in Picture) mode

Properties.Name: NameProcess
Properties.Caption: UniqueName
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] The unique name of the robot when it starts. This name will be taken into account when writing robot logs and when sending messages to the orchestrator. All messages in the orchestrator will begin with the value specified in this property

Properties.Name: WaitForExit
Properties.Caption: WaitForExit
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the block will wait for the running robot to complete.

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Waiting time for a running robot to terminate. Set in seconds. The property works if the "Wait for completion" property is enabled. A value of -1 indicates an indefinitely long wait

Properties.Name: ProcessArguments
Properties.Caption: Arguments
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Arguments for starting the robot. To edit the value, you must use the button on the block with the hint "Arguments". This function can only be used if the "Wait for completion" property is enabled. The variables used in the arguments in the called robot must be set as global

Properties.Name: RobotID
Properties.Caption: RobotID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable that stores the ID of the robot

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows you to check the completion status of the execution of a script launched using the "Start Robot" block, including the ability to check the status of several robots running in parallel at once

Properties.Name: RobotID
Properties.Caption: RobotID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable that stores the ID of the robot

Properties.Name: WaitSuccess
Properties.Caption: WaitForExit
Properties.Tooltip: The block will wait for the completion of the execution of the robot or the list of robots, and only after that it will exit via the "Yes" connector

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorDirection
Properties.Caption: OutputDirection
Properties.Tooltip: Select a block output direction in case of a failure. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Right" - to the right; "Bottom" - to the bottom. With this option, it is possible to determine output direction for blocks with no "If Error" connector (for example, "Condition" block) in case of an error. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Connector

Mouse click on an application element — a button, a checkbox, an input field, an element in the list, a menu item, etc. The click can be made even if the element is not visible on the screen (you need to scroll the window or list). This block can also be used to select a list element by its text or sequence number.

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier. If the selector is empty, the click will be made using the preset offsets from the current cursor position

Properties.Name: Action
Properties.Caption: Action
Properties.Tooltip: Action selection: left button click, double click, right button click, point the mouse cursor

Properties.Name: KeyModifier
Properties.Caption: KeyModifier
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Specifies the modifier key that will be pressed when clicked. Possible values: "CTRL", "SHIFT", "ALT", "SPACE". It is possible to specify a key combination, for example: "CTRL+SHIFT"

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: Process ID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable where a process ID is stored in. Defines an application to operate with. If the application window is minimized or overlapped with other windows, it will be on top. In case of operation in browsers, process ID additionally indicates a certain tab where a block shall operate. When blank or process ID variable is not assigned before the application start or a browser opening, the application and tab will be defined based on the content of corresponding selector string. Process ID may be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Start Application or Get Process.

Properties.Name: DelayBefore
Properties.Caption: PreDelay
Properties.Tooltip: Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

Properties.Name: DelayAfter
Properties.Caption: PostDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, after a block execution

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum waiting time for a preset element, in seconds

Properties.Name: AutoScroll
Properties.Caption: AutoScroll
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the list will automatically scroll to an element that is outside the visible area.

Properties.Name: OffsetX
Properties.Caption: OffsetX
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click X offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: OffsetY
Properties.Caption: OffsetY
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click Y offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: Selector2
Properties.Caption: WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier. If the selector is empty, the block will not wait for this element to appear

Properties.Name: AppearTypeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitType WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: Wait type selection. Appear — appearance, Disappear — disappearance

Properties.Name: DelayBeforeSelector2
Properties.Caption: DelayBefore WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Delay before checking the wait selector

Properties.Name: WaitTimeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitTime WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The maximum waiting time of the element specified in the waiting selector in seconds

Properties.Name: AttemptsSelector2
Properties.Caption: NumberAttempts WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The number of attempts for the wait selector. If the waiting selector is not found, the block will click on the main selector.

Properties.Name: SimulateMove
Properties.Caption: MotionSimulation
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the mouse cursor motion from the current position to the point calculated by the block will be simulated

Properties.Name: SimulateMessages
Properties.Caption: ClickSimulation
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, a WM message will be sent to the element to emulate a click

Properties.Name: AbsolutePoint
Properties.Caption: AbsolutePoint
Properties.Tooltip: If enabled, then the "Offset X" and "Offset Y" properties will be used as absolute coordinates for the click. If the selector is not set, then the click will be made at these coordinates

Properties.Name: NewProcessID
Properties.Caption: NewProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance]  If the process should change as a result of the block run, then its identifier will be written to the variable specified here. In most cases, this property and the Process ID property can use the same variable.

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier

Properties.Name: OverTime
Properties.Caption: HoldTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Hold time in seconds

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: SimulateMove
Properties.Caption: MotionSimulation
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the mouse cursor motion from the current position to the point calculated by the block will be simulated

Properties.Name: ProcessID

If the application window is minimized or overlapped with other windows, it will be on top. Properties.Name: KeysValue
Properties.Caption: Keys

Within the same block, you can combine continuous text input and keystrokes. To record key combinations, go to the selector window and click the "Record" button

Properties.Name: InteractiveType
Properties.Caption: Interactive
Properties.Tooltip: If set, pauses will be inserted between keystrokes. We recommend enabling this property if, due to the features of the application or web page, individual letters are lost during text input emulation.

Properties.Name: InteractiveDelay
Properties.Caption: InteractiveDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] If Interactive property is set, the pause specified here in milliseconds will be inserted between keystrokes

Properties.Name: SelectAll
Properties.Caption: SelectAll
Properties.Tooltip: Before starting input, send the "select all" key combination (Ctrl+A).

Properties.Name: OnlyText
Properties.Caption: OnlyText
Properties.Tooltip: If enabled, then all text is treated as characters and will not be split into control keys

Properties.Caption: PreDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

Properties.Caption: PostDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, after a block execution

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum waiting time for a preset element, in seconds

Properties.Name: OffsetX
Properties.Caption: OffsetX
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click X offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: OffsetY
Properties.Caption: OffsetY
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click Y offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: Selector2
Properties.Caption: WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier. If the selector is empty, the block will not wait for this element to appear

Properties.Name: AppearTypeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitType WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: Choosing the type of waiting. Appear After - appearance after text input, DisappearAfter - disappearance after text input; AppearBefore - appearance before text input; DisappearBefore -disappearance before text input. When selecting After, a mouse click will be made first, then text input, then checking the waiting selector. When selecting Before, a mouse click will be made first, then a check of the waiting selector, then text input

Properties.Name: DelayBeforeSelector2
Properties.Caption: DelayBefore WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Delay before checking the wait selector

Properties.Name: WaitTimeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitTime WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The maximum waiting time of the element specified in the waiting selector in seconds

Properties.Name: AttemptsSelector2
Properties.Caption: NumberAttempts WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The number of attempts for the wait selector. If the waiting selector is not found, the block will click on the main selector.

Properties.Name: AutoScroll

Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the list will automatically scroll to an element that is outside the visible area.

Properties.Name: SimulateMove

Properties.Name: SimulateMessages

Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, a WM message will be sent to the element to emulate a click

Properties.Name: AutoDepressing

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Clearing the internal cache of the selectors. When using selectors, the internal cache is used to speed up the search for elements on the page. Information about the element is entered into the cache after its successful identification, and in the future, when searching for the element, the cache is first checked. If there is information on this selector in the cache, it is retrieved from it, which significantly speeds up the robot's work. However, in some cases, this cache may negatively affect the script run. This is often observed in recurrent processing of elements of the same type on the same page, for example, search results. In such cases, we recommend clearing the cache when starting each iteration of iterating through the elements of the same type on the page.

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Managing the internal cache of selectors. When using selectors, the internal cache is used to speed up the search for elements on the page. Information about the element is entered into the cache after its successful identification, and in the future, when searching for the element, the cache is first checked. If there is information on this selector in the cache, it is retrieved from it, which significantly speeds up the robot's work. However, in some cases, this cache may negatively affect the script run. This is often observed in recurrent processing of elements of the same type on the same page, for example, search results. In such cases, we recommend disabling the cache using this block. If no such block is used in the project, the selector cache is enabled by default.

Properties.Name: EnableCache
Properties.Caption: Enable
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the robot will use the internal cache when searching for elements in browsers. By default, the selector cache is enabled at the project-wide level. Use this property to disable the cache, and then, if necessary, enable it back

Properties.Name: EnableDescendant
Properties.Caption: UseDescendantSearch
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, if the selector element is not found, an attempt will be made to find it as a child of the previous element. In some programs, there are a lot of such descendants (for example, 1C) and it is recommended to disable this option

Properties.Name: CountEntryDescendant
Properties.Caption: SearchDepthDescendants
Properties.Tooltip: Depth to search for descendants from the current selector element. If the selector element is not found and the "Use descendant search" option is enabled, then the selector element will be searched as a child of the current element. This value specifies the level depth to which the robot must dive to search. The larger the value, the longer the search for the selector element can take. For example, if there is no element (buttons, inscriptions), then the search before an error occurs can be long

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Scrolling with the mouse by a given amount

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier

Properties.Name: WheelDelta
Properties.Caption: Delta
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Delta to scroll to. The value indicates the number of clicks of the mouse wheel: a positive value - the wheel moves away from the user (scrolling up), negative - towards the user (scrolling down)

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: ProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable that stores the process identifier and browser tabs used by this block. If the property is left empty, or if the Process ID variable was not previously assigned at the time of opening the browser, the application and the browser tab will be defined from the contents of the corresponding selector string. Process ID can be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Launch IE, Launch Chrome or Attach To Browser.

Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Emulate keystrokes on a keyboard. Can emulate both continuous text input and keystrokes, as well as any combination of special keys and text. As part of combinations, not only keyboard keys, but also mouse keys can be used. To record key combinations, go to the selector window and click the "Record" button

Properties.Name: KeysValue
Properties.Caption: Keys
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] The text or keys to be emulated. For example: "Test text" - keys for entering this string will be emulated; "[ENTER]" - the Enter key will be pressed. Within the same block, you can combine continuous text input and keystrokes. To record key combinations, go to the selector window and click the "Record" button

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: ProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable where a process ID is stored in. Defines an application to operate with. If the application window is minimized or overlapped with other windows, it will be on top. In case of operation in browsers, process ID additionally indicates a certain tab where a block shall operate. When blank or process ID variable is not assigned before the application start or a browser opening, the application and tab will be defined based on the content of corresponding selector string. Process ID may be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Start Application or Get Process.

Properties.Name: InteractiveType
Properties.Caption: Interactive
Properties.Tooltip: If set, pauses will be inserted between keystrokes. We recommend enabling this property if, due to the features of the application or web page, individual letters are lost during text input emulation.

Properties.Name: InteractiveDelay
Properties.Caption: InteractiveDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] If Interactive property is set, the pause specified here in milliseconds will be inserted between keystrokes

Properties.Name: SelectAll
Properties.Caption: SelectAll
Properties.Tooltip: Before starting input, send the "select all" key combination (Ctrl+A).

Properties.Name: OnlyText
Properties.Caption: OnlyText
Properties.Tooltip: If enabled, then all text is treated as characters and will not be split into control keys

Properties.Name: DelayBefore
Properties.Caption: PreDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

Properties.Name: DelayAfter
Properties.Caption: PostDelay
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, after a block execution

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum waiting time for a preset element, in seconds

Properties.Name: OffsetX
Properties.Caption: OffsetX
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click X offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: OffsetY
Properties.Caption: OffsetY
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative click Y offset from the upper-left corner of the element. If no value is specified (the property is empty), then the center of the element will be used as the click point

Properties.Name: Selector2
Properties.Caption: WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier. If the selector is empty, the block will not wait for this element to appear

Properties.Name: AppearTypeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitType WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: Choosing the type of waiting. Appear After - appearance after text input, DisappearAfter - disappearance after text input; AppearBefore - appearance before text input; DisappearBefore -disappearance before text input. When selecting After, a mouse click will be made first, then text input, then checking the waiting selector. When selecting Before, a mouse click will be made first, then a check of the waiting selector, then text input

Properties.Name: DelayBeforeSelector2
Properties.Caption: DelayBefore WaitingSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Delay before checking the wait selector

Properties.Name: WaitTimeSelector2
Properties.Caption: WaitTime WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The maximum waiting time of the element specified in the waiting selector in seconds

Properties.Name: AttemptsSelector2
Properties.Caption: NumberAttempts WaitiningSelector
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The number of attempts for the wait selector. If the waiting selector is not found, the block will click on the main selector.

Properties.Name: AutoScroll
Properties.Caption: AutoScroll
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the list will automatically scroll to an element that is outside the visible area.

Properties.Name: SimulateMove
Properties.Caption: MotionSimulation
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the mouse cursor motion from the current position to the point calculated by the block will be simulated

Properties.Name: SimulateMessages
Properties.Caption: ClickSimulation
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, a WM message will be sent to the element to emulate a click

Properties.Name: AutoDepressing
Properties.Caption: AutoDepressing
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, pressed keys (with a + modifier, for example [+CTRL]) will be automatically released after block execution. If the property is disabled, then you must manually release the previously held key (with the - modifier, for example [-CTRL])

Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable that stores the process identifier and browser tabs used by this block. If the property is left empty, or if the Process ID variable was not previously assigned at the time of opening the browser, the application and the browser tab will be defined from the contents of the corresponding selector string. Process ID can be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Launch IE, Launch Chrome or Attach To Browser.

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: The block allows for retrieving the same type of structured data from web pages (search results, menu items, lists, tables, etc.) and putting them in a variable in the form of a data table. To specify the required data source and retrieval settings, use the "Scrape Data" button on the Designer toolbar or the "Record" button in the Selector edit window of this block.

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] Identifier of the browser window and the web page element, or a set of similar elements (headers, links, text blocks, etc.) to be retrieved

Properties.Name: Selector2
Properties.Caption: NextPage
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] Selector to go to the next page. If it is set, data will be automatically collected from all pages.

Properties.Name: OffsetX2
Properties.Caption: NextPageXOffset
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative X offset from the upper-left corner of the target element of the next page.

Properties.Name: OffsetY2
Properties.Caption: NextPageYOffset
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Relative Y offset from the upper-left corner of the target element of the next page.

Properties.Name: DelayPage
Properties.Caption: PauseNextPage
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The pause time after clicking on the next page element in seconds. It can be used if the data on the page is updated via AJAX

Properties.Name: PageCount
Properties.Caption: NumberPages
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] The number of pages being processed. If the value is not set or is zero, then all possible pages are processed as long as the next page element is available

Properties.Name: RowsCount
Properties.Caption: RowsCount
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum number of rows to retrieve

Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum waiting time for a preset element, in seconds

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] User interface element identifier

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: ProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable where a process ID is stored in. Defines an application to operate with. If the application window is minimized or overlapped with other windows, it will be on top. In case of operation in browsers, process ID additionally indicates a certain tab where a block shall operate. When blank or process ID variable is not assigned before the application start or a browser opening, the application and tab will be defined based on the content of corresponding selector string. Process ID may be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Start Application or Get Process.

Properties.Name: Сondition
Properties.Caption: Сondition
Properties.Tooltip: The condition that needs to be checked. Possible values: CheckExists - check the element; CheckAttribute - check the attribute; Checked - check the installation; Focused - check the focus

Properties.Name: CompareValue

Properties.Tooltip: [Any Type] The value with which the received attribute value will be compared

Properties.Name: CompareReply
Properties.Caption: CompareReply
Properties.Tooltip: [Any Type] The expected value after verification. If the value obtained as a result of the check is different from the specified one, the block will exit by mistake

Properties.Tooltip: Attribute name

Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Time delay, in seconds, prior to a block execution

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Sends an asynchronous GET request and receives the return page code. After the request enqueueing, the block immediately returns control. Next, you can still queue queries, as well as check the current number of threads. If there is no longer a need to queue requests and the current number of threads is zero, then the work of the block can be considered completed. If the block gets out via the "Wait" connector, it means that the pre-defined maximum number of threads is exceeded and you should wait until they get free. If the block gets out via the "Processing" connector, then the thread has completed its work and the result can be processed. At the same time, if the variable from the "Error Text" property is empty, it means that there were no errors during the thread, otherwise you can find out what error occurred

Properties.Caption: NumberOfErrors
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Maximum number of errors for each request. If an error occurs during processing of the request, then after reaching the pre-defined number, this request will be removed from the queue without generating a result and an error message.

Properties.Name: Parameters
Properties.Caption: Parameters
Properties.Tooltip: [Hashtable] Parameters to be passed to the called method. If the value is not set, but the name of the method is set, then the list of input parameters of the method will be returned

Properties.Name: Username
Properties.Caption: Username
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Login for basic authorization

Properties.Name: Password
Properties.Caption: Password
Properties.Tooltip: [Text/SecureString] Password for basic authorization

Properties.Name: UseWindowsCredentials
Properties.Caption: WindowsAuthorisation
Properties.Tooltip: Use Windows Authorization

Properties.Name: Timeout
Properties.Caption: Timeout
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] [Number] Waiting time for the operation in seconds

Properties.Name: UseSoap12
Properties.Caption: UseSoap12
Properties.Tooltip: Includes Soap12 protocol

Properties.Name: UseMtom
Properties.Caption: UseMtom
Properties.Tooltip: Enables Mtom transfer mode

Properties.Name: Result
Properties.Caption: Result
Properties.Tooltip: [List / Hashtable / Text] The result of the work. Depending on the mode, it takes the following values: if the "Method name" property is not set, then returns a List with all supported methods; If the "Method Name" property is set, but "Parameters" is not set, then returns a Hashtable with a list of the input data of this method; If both properties are set, then returns the result of the executed query

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Recognizes the pre-defined document by a template

Properties.Name: FileName
Properties.Caption: FilePath
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] File path. Supported file formats: .png;.jpg;.pdf. The pdf file can be multi-page

Properties.Name: FilePattern
Properties.Caption: TemplateFilePath
Properties.Tooltip: [Text/List] Path to the template file for recognition. When specifying a list of template files for recognition, each file will be used sequentially until recognition is successful. If none of the templates is suitable for the document, an exception will be generated with the error of the first template from the list

Properties.Name: PageIndex
Properties.Caption: PageNumber
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Page number in a multi-page pdf file

Properties.Name: ReplaceModule
Properties.Caption: ReplaceModule
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Allows you to replace the specified module in the template with the one specified in the block during recognition. Possible values: TesseractOCR; YandexVision; Microsoft OCR AbbyyOCR; FineReader

Properties.Name: ReplaceScale
Properties.Caption: ReplaceScale
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Sets the new scale when recognized by the pattern. If the value is not set, then the scale from the template settings is used, otherwise the scale specified in this property is set

Properties.Name: ReplaceLanguages
Properties.Caption: ReplaceLanguages
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Allows for recognition to replace the specified language in the template with the one specified in the block. Possible values: Eng Rus;Eng;Rus. To specify your own values for the recognition language, write it down like this: "Custom:eng+rus"

Properties.Name: ReplaceHorizCellScale
Properties.Caption: ReplaceHorizCellScale
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Sets the new size of the cell horizontally when recognized by the pattern. If the value is not set, then the cell size from the template settings is used, otherwise the size specified in this property is set

Properties.Name: ReplaceVertCellScale
Properties.Caption: ReplaceVertCellScale
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Sets the new size of the cell vertically when recognized by the template. If the value is not set, then the cell size from the template settings is used, otherwise the size specified in this property is set

Properties.Name: AddTableConfidence
Properties.Caption: AddConfidenceTable
Properties.Tooltip: When the parameter is enabled, the CellData object, not the text, will be written to each cell of the table. It will be possible to extract text from the object using the Text property, as well as the percentage of "confidence" using the Confidence property

Properties.Name: IgnoreAnchorErrors
Properties.Caption: IgnoreAnchorErrors
Properties.Tooltip: If anchors (any) are not found, no errors will be generated. In this case, the anchor area is considered zero

Properties.Name: ProcesssingAllPages
Properties.Caption: ProcessAllPages
Properties.Tooltip: When this option is enabled, all pages in the document will be processed. This mode does not check the LastPage anchor

Properties.Name: Attributes
Properties.Caption: Attributes
Properties.Tooltip: [Hashtable] Hashtable with document attributes. For example: "Document number", "Supplier's INN", etc.

Properties.Name: Tables
Properties.Caption: Tables
Properties.Tooltip: [Data Table List] List of data tables is returned. The list is formed based on data from the template

Properties.Name: Anchors
Properties.Caption: Anchors
Properties.Tooltip: [Hashtable] Hashtable with found anchors. The key of the Hashtable is the anchor ID, and the value is a rectangle indicating its position on the page. In this case, the DPI of the page is taken as 300

Properties.Name: AreaAttributes
Properties.Caption: AttributeData
Properties.Tooltip: [Dictionary] Dictionary with found attributes. The dictionary key is the attribute name, and the value is an object with attribute data. The object contains a rectangle indicating the position of the attribute on the page. In this case, the DPI of the page is taken as 300. The object also contains a Confidence value indicating "Confidence" in recognition. Available for Tesseract and Yandex Vision and has a value from 0 to 100

Properties.Name: IndexPattern
Properties.Caption: IndexPattern
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Index of the recognized pattern. This property is relevant if a list is specified in the "Path to the template file" property. Numbering starts from zero

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: This block can be used to set a screen area (application window, panel or other element inside the window), one or more words during the robot development, and write the coordinates of the click with respect to the location of these words inside the screen area, and then, during the script execution, the robot will recognize all text from the preset area of the screen using OCR technology, find a similar section of the screen with the preset text, and then click the point with the previously stored coordinates with respect to the upper-left corner of the found text. You can choose one from several available offline and online OCR modules. This block is especially useful for clicking on controls in applications and on web pages, in which it is not possible to find stable selectors for the required element, or if the application window looks like a single picture for the operating system (for example, in the case of working with the application via remote access).

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] Identifier of the window or user interface element, within which text recognition will be performed

Properties.Name: Action
Properties.Caption: Action
Properties.Tooltip: Action selection: left button click, double click, right button click

Properties.Name: OCRTextX
Properties.Caption: Xcoordinate
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Horizontal coordinate of the upper-left corner of the area of the selected window or control, in which image capture and recognition will be performed

Properties.Name: OCRTextY
Properties.Caption: Ycoordinate
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Vertical coordinate of the upper-left corner of the area of the selected window or control, in which image capture and recognition will be performed

Properties.Name: OCRTextWidth
Properties.Caption: Width
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Image width for capture and recognition in pixels

Properties.Name: OCRTextHeight
Properties.Caption: Height
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Image height for capture and recognition in pixels

Properties.Name: OCRTextPointX
Properties.Caption: ClickXCoordinate
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Horizontal offset of the click coordinate relative to the upper-left corner of the found text block on the screen

Properties.Name: OCRTextPointY
Properties.Caption: ClickYCoordinate
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Vertical offset of the click coordinate relative to the upper-left corner of the found text block on the element

Properties.Name: OCRTextLanguages
Properties.Caption: TextLanguage
Properties.Tooltip: Text languages selection. Language options depend on available OCR modules.

Properties.Name: OCRTextFindText
Properties.Caption: TextSearch
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Search for text in the recognized image. If set, the mouse click will be made relative to the upper-left corner of the found text block, otherwise — relative to the upper-left corner of the screen area specified by the coordinates

Properties.Name: OCRTextFindPercent
Properties.Caption: HitRatio
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Sought text hit ratio, from 0 to 100. Reduce this number so that the text you are looking for is found even in case of inaccuracies in text recognition. Too low ratio value will lead to a hit to unnecessary words

Properties.Name: OCRTextOccurence
Properties.Caption: HitIndex
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] If the sought text is found in the specified area of the screen several times, you can specify the sequence number of the hit that you want to use for the click. Numbering starts from 1

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: ProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Variable where a process ID is stored in. Defines an application to operate with. If the application window is minimized or overlapped with other windows, it will be on top. In case of operation in browsers, process ID additionally indicates a certain tab where a block shall operate. When blank or process ID variable is not assigned before the application start or a browser opening, the application and tab will be defined based on the content of corresponding selector string. Process ID may be retrieved, for example, by means of blocks Start Application or Get Process.

Properties.Name: OCRTextModule
Properties.Caption: Module
Properties.Tooltip: Select OCR module for text recognition on an image

Properties.Name: OCRTextScale
Properties.Caption: Zoom
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] A value stating the zoom factor for an image prior to recognition. Depending on a drive used, with 2 or 3 times zoomed image it is possible to improve quality of recognition

Properties.Name: SimulateMove
Properties.Caption: SimulateMove
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the movement of the mouse cursor from the current position to the point calculated by the block will be simulated

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Release" - deactivated output; "Debug" - main information output; "Detailed" - detailed information output. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ErrorMessage
Properties.Caption: ErrorText
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Display detailed error information in case of a block failure

ItemsSettings.DisplayName: Click on Recognized Text from Element

This block is especially useful for clicking on controls in applications and on web pages that cannot find stable selectors for the required element, or if the application window looks like one picture to the operating system (for example, when working with the application through remote control tools). Properties.Name: QueueGuid
Properties.Caption: QueueGUID/Name
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Queue GUID or Name

Properties.Name: Name
Properties.Caption: Name
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Task name

Properties.Name: Description
Properties.Caption: Description
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Description of the task

Properties.Name: Parameters
Properties.Caption: Parameters
Properties.Tooltip: [Date and Time/Text] If the time specified in this property has already passed, the task will receive the highest priority in the queue. that is, when the robot receives the next task from the queue in order of priority, this task will be received before tasks with a priority of "High".

Properties.Name: PostponedTo
Properties.Caption: PostponedTo
Properties.Tooltip: [Date and time/Text] The processing of the task will be postponed till the specified moment. Once the specified moment has passed, the orchestrator will automatically change the Status of this task into "New".

Properties.Name: Deadline
Properties.Caption: Deadline
Properties.Tooltip: [DateTime] If the time specified here has already passed, this task will get the highest priority in queue, so when robot gets next task from queue in the order of priority, this task will be obtained earlier than any other task with "High" priority

Properties.Name: Priority
Properties.Caption: Priority
Properties.Tooltip: Task priority. Possible values: Low - low; Normal - normal; High - high

Properties.Name: TagNames
Properties.Caption: Tags
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Semicolon-separated list of tags

Properties.Name: Comment
Properties.Tooltip: Comment

Properties.Name: CreatedLater
Properties.Caption: CreatedLater
Properties.Tooltip: [Date and Time/Text] If the property is filled, the result will include only those tasks whose CreatedAt is greater than or equal to the value of this field. When specifying a date in text format, you must use the format "dd.MM.yyyy HH:mm:ss"

Properties.Name: MarkInProgress
Properties.Caption: MarkInProgress
Properties.Tooltip: If selected, the status of the task will be immediately changed to "In Progress"

Properties.Name: ReWriteParameters
Properties.Caption: OverwriteParametersObject
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the already specified parameter object will be overwritten. It is relevant for a data table if a reference to a row of this table is used. When the parameter is disabled, the link to the string will not be lost.

Properties.Name: ErrorWhenZeroTasks
Properties.Caption: ErrorWhenZeroTasks
Properties.Tooltip: When the property is enabled, if the task is not found, an error will be generated, otherwise $null will be returned in the "TaskObject" property

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName:
The block allows you to create your own windows (forms) and display them in modal and non-modal mode, including asynchronously with respect to the diagram flow. If a selector is set, the coordinates of the created window will be bound to a control in another application. To create and edit your window, use the "Edit..." button of the block, and to create reusable windows, use the "Window Editor" button on the main toolbar. Each call to this block shows or updates the window data (if the window is already on the screen). If the window is not modal, calling the "Custom Window" block again allows you to dynamically update the controls in the window and the variables that are bound to the window elements.

The values of each of the controls, as well as user actions in the window, can be linked to changes in the values of the selected variables, and vice versa - changing the values of variables leads to changes in the values of the corresponding controls. This functionality allows you to develop branched dialog and expert systems, robot settings windows, interactive prompts and assistants, as well as entire multi-window applications within the robot script.

Properties.Name: Configuration
Properties.Caption: Configuration
Properties.Tooltip: [Text/Object] Configuration string. To edit the value, use the button on the "Edit" block.

Properties.Name: ExistsWindowObject
Properties.Caption: ExistsWindowObject
Properties.Tooltip: [Object] Variable with window object. The window object can be obtained from the previous "Show window" block in the script and this is relevant for displaying a window in a non-modal mode

Properties.Name: IsModal
Properties.Caption: IsModal
Properties.Tooltip: When enabled, the window will be shown as modal. Otherwise, after the window is displayed, control will immediately go to the script

Properties.Name: Selector
Properties.Caption: Selector
Properties.Tooltip: [Selector] Identifier of the browser window and the web page element

Properties.Name: ProcessID
Properties.Caption: ProcessID
Properties.Tooltip: [Reference] A variable that stores the process ID. Specifies which application to work with. If the specified application is minimized or its window is covered by other windows, it will be brought to the foreground. When working with browsers, the process ID additionally indicates the specific browser tab that the block should work with. If the property is left blank, or if the process ID variable was not previously set when the application was launched or the browser was opened, the application and browser tab will be determined from the contents of the corresponding selector string. The process ID can be obtained, for example, using the Run application or Get process blocks.

Properties.Name: ThumbImage
Properties.Caption: ThumbImage
Properties.Tooltip: Thumb Image

Properties.Name: AngleBinding
Properties.Caption: AngleBinding
Properties.Tooltip: Selects the value of the window snap angle. If the selector is set, then the value specifies the binding of the upper left corner of the window to the corner of the found element (in this case, the "Default" value will point to the center of the element). If a selector is specified but not found, then any value of the property will display the window in the middle of the window. If the selector is not set, then the property specifies the binding of the window to the working area of the main screen.

Properties.Name: OffsetX
Properties.Caption: OffsetX
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] X offset when displaying the window. If the selector is not set and the anchor angle is "Default", and this property has a value, then this value will be considered absolute coordinates for displaying the window

Properties.Name: OffsetY
Properties.Caption: OffsetY
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Y offset when displaying the window. If the selector is not set and the anchor angle is "Default", and this property has a value, then this value will be considered absolute coordinates for displaying the window

Properties.Name: ControlEvent
Properties.Caption: ControlEvent
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Event generated by the element on the form. Value format: "ControlName.EventName". If a button on a form contains a DialogResult value, then that value will be specified in this property. For example: "OK", "Cancel"

Properties.Name: WindowObject
Properties.Caption: WindowObject
Properties.Tooltip: [Object] The created window object is returned. This property is useful when showing a window without using a modal. To do this, specify a variable from this property in the next block. In this case, the data in the window will be updated without creating a new instance of the window.

Properties.Name: ErrorLevel
Properties.Caption: HandlingMode
Properties.Tooltip: Select error-handling mode. Possible settings: "Default" - by default; "Ignore" - ignore errors; "Handle" - handle errors. If "Default" is selected, a value of "Start" block of the diagram will be used.

Properties.Name: ReportLevel
Properties.Caption: MessageLevel
Properties.Tooltip: Select the level of messages to output blocks during operation. Properties.Name: ErrorMessage

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: Show the user a modal dialog box with the preset header, text and a set of buttons. If a window with several buttons is used, the block allows you to write to a variable a character literal corresponding to the button pressed by the user.

Properties.Name: Title
Properties.Caption: Title
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Text, variable value, or expression result that will be displayed in the header of the dialog box

Properties.Name: Message
Properties.Caption: Message
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Text, variable value, or expression result that will be displayed inside the dialog box

Properties.Name: Buttons
Properties.Caption: Buttons
Properties.Tooltip: Buttons that will be available to the user to click

Properties.Name: MessageImage
Properties.Caption: Image
Properties.Tooltip: Image that will be displayed in the dialog box

Properties.Name: WaitTime
Properties.Caption: WaitTime
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Waiting time. If a value greater than zero is set, the window will automatically close after this time. In this case, the last value specified in the "Buttons" property will be written to the "Result" property.

Properties.Name: WordWrap
Properties.Caption: WordWrap
Properties.Tooltip: Line wrapping is enabled

Properties.Name: Result
Properties.Caption: Result
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Variable, in which the name of the button pressed by the user will be saved. One of the possible results: OK, Cancel, Yes, No. These character literals do not depend on the robot's or operating system's language

Properties.Name: Filter
Properties.Caption: Filter
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] If necessary, you can set a file filter. For each filter parameter, the filter string contains the filter description, followed by a vertical bar (|) and a filter template. Strings for various filtering parameters are separated by a vertical line. For example: "Text files (*.txt)|*.txt|All files (*.*)|*.*" - the dialog will give a choice between two parameters: "Text files (*.txt)" and "All files (*.*)"

ItemsSettings.FriendlyName: This block allows you to show your end-user “Man in the Loop” window which can be used to double-check lists, hashtables and tables; make edits in real time and compare images with text data (for example scanned documents with their OCRed text versions). In the block properties, you can specify the necessary data for viewing and editing. Unused properties should be left empty

Properties.Caption: FilePath

Properties.Name: CustomButtonsNames
Properties.Caption: MyNames
Properties.Tooltip: [Text] User's button names to display in the box. To use this property, select "Custom" in the "Button Names" property. Names are separated by the / symbol: for example, "Name1/Name2"

Properties.Name: OutList

Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Returns an instance of the Word document processing

Properties.Caption: DocumentInstance
Properties.Tooltip: [Instance] Returns an instance of the open Word document, in which the work is currently taking place

Properties.Name: UseCOM
Properties.Caption: UseCOM
Properties.Tooltip: If checked, then the work will take place using the installed Word. Otherwise, without it.

Properties.Name: Visible
Properties.Caption: Visibility
Properties.Tooltip: If the "Use COM" check mark and the "Visibility" check mark are put, then the Word interface will be displayed on the monitor screen. If the "Use COM" check mark is put, and the "Visibility" check mark is not, then the work will be with Word physically running in memory with its box invisible on the screen. If the "Use COM" check mark is not put, then the value of the "Visibility" property will not be taken into account.

Properties.Name: StartIndexChar

Properties.Name: EndIndexChar
Properties.Caption: SymbolFinalIndex
Properties.Tooltip: [Number] Final index of the symbol for search. Numbering starts from 0. If the "Page Final Index" property is set and it is greater than zero, then this property is ignored

Properties.Name: Result
Properties.Caption: FragmentList
Properties.Tooltip: [List] List of instances of the Range object. Examples of available properties: applicable to the first element of the array (with index 0), $ListRanges[0].Start - symbol initial index; $ListRanges[0].End - symbol final index; $ListRanges[0].Text - fragment text. To replace the text in the document for this fragment, assign a new value to the Text property, for example: $ListRanges[0].Text = "New text"

Properties.Tooltip: [Text] Macro file. If the property is set, then this file will be loaded into the VBA environment before running. The file extension must be ".bas"
